# **Main references: Weak convergence**

1. [Convergence of Probability measures](http://search.lib.unc.edu/search?R=UNCb2554346). Large parts of the course follow the 1968 book but we cover an assorted collection of special topics and examples. 

2. [Durret's Probability Theory and examples](https://services.math.duke.edu/~rtd/PTE/PTEv5a.pdf)
Fantastic treatment of the Martingale FCLT in Chapter 8. 

# **Main references: Local weak convergence**

1. [Aldous and Steele's survey on the Objective method.](https://www.stat.berkeley.edu/~aldous/Papers/me101.pdf) Beautiful survey of the applications of the method in probabilistic combinatorial optimization by two masters in the field. 

2. [Benjamini and Schramm's work on distribution limits of Planar graphs.](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.ejp/1461097653)

3. [Dembo and Montanari's work on Gibbs measures on sparse random graphs](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.bjps/1271770268). Also see their [Annals of  Probability paper.](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.aoap/1268143433)

4. [Side reading: Chapter 8 of Bishop's pattern recognition and machine learning](http://www.springer.com/us/book/9780387310732). Gives a nice overview of probabilistic graphical models. In particular Section 4 on message passing algorithms and their role in computing marginal distributions in the context of Markov random fields especially when the graphical structure is tree like was a fun read. 

# **Additional Readings**

<a name="advice">
 **Advice for graduate students**
</a>

- [Aldous's review of Spin glasses by Talagrand](https://www.stat.berkeley.edu/~aldous/Misc/talagrand.pdf)
- [J. Michael's Steele's semi-random rants](http://www-stat.wharton.upenn.edu/~steele/Rants.htm)
Lots of valuable advice for graduate students.
- [Andrew Wiles's advice for math research](https://mathwithbaddrawings.com/2017/09/20/the-state-of-being-stuck/) "But being stuck, Wiles said, isn’t failure. “It’s part of the process. It’s not something to be frightened of.”"

<a name="metric">
 **Metric space fundamentals**
</a>

- [STOR BIOS Boot camp](http://storbiosbootcamp.web.unc.edu)


<a name="clt">
 **Central Limit Theorem**
</a>

- [Alan Turing and the CLT](https://www.jstor.org/stable/2974762?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents) Also has a nice description of the connections between statistics and Turing's work during World War II in breaking the German enigma machine. 
- [Nice paper on extensions of the Lindeberg technique by Chatterjee](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.aop/1171377437) Extensions of Wigner's semi-circle law to exchangeable entries are also explored. 

<a name="stein">
 **Stein's method**
</a>

- [Nice survey on Normal approximation using Stein's method](https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/d305/626ef13ca557687965a9e24e89ead0ff1fea.pdf)
- [Beautiful overview of Stein-Chen for Poisson approximation](http://www.jstor.org/stable/2245366?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents)
- [Remembering Wassily Hoeffding](https://projecteuclid.org/euclid.ss/1242049393)
- [Beautiful thesis on exchangeable pairs and concentration inequalities](https://arxiv.org/abs/math/0507526)
- [Birthday problem and random trees](https://projecteuclid.org/download/pdf_1/euclid.ejp/1457376437) Describes a way of constructing random trees using the birthday problem. Deep applications in a number of other areas including the study of the entrance boundary of the additive coalescent. 

<a name="mom">
 **Method of moments**
</a>

- [Nice collection of worked out examples](https://www.fernuni-hagen.de/stochastik/downloads/momente.pdf)
- [A powerful example by a master of the field (Svante Janson)](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1307.6344.pdf)
- [Not MOM but a beautiful branch of applied probability: Power of two choices](https://www.eecs.harvard.edu/~michaelm/postscripts/handbook2001.pdf)

<a name="cramer-wold">
 **Cramer-Wold device**
</a>

- [First 3 pages of this article has a nice application](https://people.orie.cornell.edu/gennady/techreports/NormalityCountsSGSG.pdf)

<a name="AS">
 **Compactness/Arzela-Ascoli**
</a>

- [Comprehensive discussion of compactness etc on Terry Tao's blog](https://terrytao.wordpress.com/2009/02/09/245b-notes-10-compactness-in-topological-spaces/)

<a name="bm">
 **Brownian Motion**
</a>

As one might imagine, references for Brownian motion are almost infinite. The following two are most closely related to our class.

- [Chapters 7 and 8 of Durrett: Probability Theory and examples](https://services.math.duke.edu/~rtd/PTE/PTE4_1.pdf)
- [Chapters 1 and 2 of Morters and Peres's book on Brownian motion](http://yuvalperes.com/brbook.pdf)
